explanation: The report is not correct. The four (void) parameter casts are the usual idiom to mark deliberately unused parameters and to silence compiler warnings; they are not the sort of “dead code” that MISRA Rule 2.2 intends to forbid. Rule 2.2 targets operations whose removal would have no effect on program behaviour. While a plain (void)expr expression-statement performs no observable state change, it is intentionally present to document intent and suppress warnings and — as MISRA Note 1 reminds — executed statements can affect timing in embedded systems, so their removal could in some contexts change behaviour. In practice this idiom is acceptable and not treated as a Rule 2.2 violation. The probe run shown does not prove a Rule 2.2 violation (and its empty log only shows the function was not exercised by the test), so the agent’s conclusion is incorrect.
